textRegions.text: Gerrit best practices
@causes
presented by
Greg Hurrell
Pro-tip #1
Don’t push unrelated changes as a group
Push them as separate commits instead
This way your reviewer won’t see dependency information and waste cycles paying attention to it
Sample workflow for a series of unrelated changes
git checkout master && git pull
vim file
git commit -m “Edited file”
git push gerrit
git fetch && git reset --hard origin/master
vim other-file
git commit -m “Edited other file”
git push gerrit
git fetch && git reset --hard origin/master
vim yet-another-file
git commit -m “Edited yet another file”
git push gerrit
Getting your stuff reviewed
the most effective way to get your stuff reviewed quickly is to pair; your pair can push your change through Gerrit immediately
next up, the most effective thing is asking a specific person for a review
the git review command-line tool makes this easy; asking works well too
trading reviews is good too: “sure I’ll review your change; would you mind looking at the review I have in the queue as well?”
adding everyone as a reviewer is generally not effective, as people tend to think somebody else will do it
Scoring
“-1” is for preventing broken/incorrect code from getting into the repo
it can also be used as a flag to stop other people wasting time reviewing something (ie. you can use it on your own patches)
comments on style are recommendations; give a “+1” if your recommendations are of the “take it or leave it” variety
Momentum
The purpose of code review is not to slow us down, but to increase the quality of our code and maximize knowledge transfer
So remember to pair as much as possible
Set up a “review buddy” who you work with routinely
Remember that in an emergency you can “+1” your own changes (Gerrit’s purpose is not to prevent you from acting)
Feel free to give “+1 verified as trivial” if the change truly is trivial (eg. removing an errant “puts” statement)
Dependencies
Gerrit knows when one commit depends on earlier commits
but...
Out-of-order submission
Because we’re using the “Cherry Pick” submission style, we have to pay attention to the dependency info and submit changes in order
Grouping together changes
You can make it easier to spot related commits with dependencies by giving them a shared topic name
This shows up in the UI, and gives the reviewer an indication that changes are grouped together
Sample workflow: amending, rebasing, resubmitting
# check out a copy of the last-submitted version
git fetch ssh://greg@gerrit.causes.com:29418/wishes refs/changes/46/1146/2 && git checkout FETCH_HEAD
# fix it
vim pesky-file
git commit --amend
# rebase it
git fetch && git rebase origin/master
# resubmit it
git push gerrit
Rebasing and fixing multiple commits
That flow will work for rebasing a series of related commits as well
Just grab the last commit in the series and run:
git fetch
git rebase -i origin/master
Your Change-Ids will be preserved, so when you do git push gerrit all of the patches in the series will be appropriately updated
Rebasing after a cherry-pick
Once a change is cherry-picked, it will be annotated and get a new SHA-1
You can continue building on top of it by rebasing:
git commit -m “Fix that bug”
git push gerrit
# then, after review and submission...
git pull --rebase
vim file # keep on working
Building off others’ work
don’t build off of other people’s unmerged changes
either make your change independent of theirs;
or review and merge their work so you can build off a solid starting point (one that won’t be revised underneath you)
Pro-tips from a special guest
These from Derewecki’s Tome of Wisdom:
rebase often
break your changes into small chunks
master should always be in a releasable state
don’t stray too far off into the weeds; try to merge your works in progress into master at least once a day
Follow through
Don’t let changes languish in the queue
Make sure your stuff gets reviewed
Be aware when your stuff gets submitted
Deploying is fast; deploy your stuff promptly so that you can follow-through on it and confirm that everything is working correctly in production
Communicate with others when you submit their work (especially if it’s something they’d want to deploy and verify personally, like a migration)
Who should submit?
for speed, you can submit other people’s changes after you review them
remember to pay attention to dependencies
if you don’t want somebody to submit your patch for some reason, give it “-1 verified” yourself
Staging
We’ve set up an unrestricted “staging/” namespace, which Gerrit will pass straight on to GitHub without holding for review:
git push origin HEAD:staging/my-topic
Staging
There is a script in our devscripts repo gerrit-stage.sh, which can be used to push a topic through to staging, stripping the Change-Ids automatically
Using git review for fun and profit
Advanced workflow
Real Topic Branch Fu (like Tofu, but with a DAG)
Creating a topic branch
HEAD
Working on the topic
When working on a topic branch, you push to “refs/for/the-topic” rather than “refs/for/master”
You review commits as you go, submitting them onto the topic rather than master
As this is a real branch, amending or rewriting already-submitted commits is a no-no (if you mutate published history, you’ll make life harder for your collaborators)
Amending commits that are still pending submission is fine
When you’re ready to merge back into master, you push the merge commit itself to “refs/for/master”
The final merge
The final merge is not so useful to review in Gerrit because the diff will be empty (like the output of git show for a merge commit)
You can see the overall picture using the “gitweb” link
Or by fetching and comparing on the command-line with something like:
git diff FETCH_HEAD^1...FETCH_HEAD^2
The final merge
master
the topic
The final merge
Push it to Gerrit immediately before submitting
If somebody else changes the master branch before you submit, your merge will no longer apply directly on top of master; rather, another merge will be required, which will uglify the graph
So it’s best to do the merge, sanity-check it, and then submit immediately
To avoid races or accidents, let the team know (eg. in Campfire) when you’re about to do such a merge
A merge of a merge
This is what things will look like if your merge gets submitted too late (after master has moved on)
Whoops!
Tips, tricks and easter eggs
Stuff you may not have noticed about Gerrit
Collaborating with other engineers
It took a lot of fiddling and experimentation, but we figured out how to allow you to push another developer’s commits
This means you can checkout somebody else’s change, fix it and resubmit it yourself if you’re in a hurry
Reviewing images
You can review images by clicking on the “new” link in the file listing
Currently enabled for MIME-type “image/*”; let me know if you want more types enabled
Viewing diffs for CSS files
currently Gerrit will choke trying to show the diff for some, but not all, CSS files
you can use the “gitweb” link to view those diffs, although obviously not directly comment on them
Copy-to-clipboard
There are widgets for quickly copying useful text to your clipboard
Patch history
use the patch history options to see the “inter-diff” between different versions of a patch
this makes it much easier to review when revisiting a change after giving feedback
Diff options
There are a number of useful settings available on the diff-viewing screen; try them out
Context
One example of a useful setting is the “Context” pop-up, which allows you to see up to an entire file of context
Settings
There is a settings section where you can do useful stuff like upping the maximum number of items shown per page
Overriding Jenkins
if Jenkins ever fails spuriously, you can override its “-1” by clicking on the “x” button alongside it in the reviewer list
if you do this, it’s a good idea to leave a comment noting what you did and why
click here
Verifying
On those occasions when Jenkins lets us down, you can either verify that the specs pass yourself and give it a “+1 verified”; or retrigger the build in the Jenkins UI
Getting around fast
Gerrit has keyboard shortcuts for almost everything
Context-sensitive shortcuts are available on each page; check them out by pressing “?”
OpenID
If you ever accidentally log in with the wrong Google account, let me know and I can unify the two identities for you
This way you won’t have to go through the cumbersome process of logging out and back in again just because you arrive at Gerrit with the wrong OpenID credentials
Letting Gerrit remember stuff for you
If you don’t like clutter, you can delete your local branches as soon as you’ve pushed them to Gerrit for review
You can always get them back easily using the download link in the Gerrit UI
Meta
